message_1:
Find the eigenvalues and eigenfunctions of the Schrödinger equation 

![equation](https://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?%5Cdpi%7B120%7D%20%5Cbg_white%20-%20%5Cfrac%7B%5Chbar%5E2%7D%7B2m%7D%5Cfrac%7Bd%5E2%7D%7Bdx%5E2%7D%5Cpsi%28x%29%20+%20V%28x%29%5Cpsi%28x%29%20%3D%20E%5Cpsi%28x%29)

where the potential is given by:

![equation](https://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?%5Cdpi%7B120%7D%20%5Cbg_white%20V%28x%29%20%3D%20a%5Cdelta%28x%29%20+%20bx%20%5C%20%20%28a%20%5C%20and%20%5C%20b%20%5C%20%20are%20%5C%20real%20%5C%20constants%20%29)

and the wavefunction is subject to the boundary conditions:

![equation](https://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?%5Cdpi%7B120%7D%20%5Cbg_white%20%5Cpsi%28-x_0%29%20%3D%20%5Cpsi%28x_0%29%20%3D%200)

where x_0 is a positive constant.
message_2:
To solve the Schrödinger equation with the given potential, we will first consider the two regions separately: x < 0 and x > 0. We will then match the solutions at x = 0, taking into account the delta function potential.

For x < 0, the potential is V(x) = bx. The Schrödinger equation becomes:

![equation](https://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?%5Cdpi%7B120%7D%20%5Cbg_white%20-%20%5Cfrac%7B%5Chbar%5E2%7D%7B2m%7D%5Cfrac%7Bd%5E2%7D%7Bdx%5E2%7D%5Cpsi_%7B-%7D%28x%29%20+%20bx%5Cpsi_%7B-%7D%28x%29%20%3D%20E%5Cpsi_%7B-%7D%28x%29)

For x > 0, the potential is V(x) = -bx. The Schrödinger equation becomes:

![equation](https://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?%5Cdpi%7B120%7D%20%5Cbg_white%20-%20%5Cfrac%7B%5Chbar%5E2%7D%7B2m%7D%5Cfrac%7Bd%5E2%7D%7Bdx%5E2%7D%5Cpsi_%7B+%7D%28x%29%20-%20bx%5Cpsi_%7B+%7D%28x%29%20%3D%20E%5Cpsi_%7B+%7D%28x%29)

These equations are linear, so we can try a power series solution for both regions:

![equation](https://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?%5Cdpi%7B120%7D%20%5Cbg_white%20%5Cpsi_%7B-%7D%28x%29%20%3D%20%5Csum_%7Bn%3D0%7D%5E%7B%5Cinfty%7D%20a_nx%5En)

![equation](https://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?%5Cdpi%7B120%7D%20%5Cbg_white%20%5Cpsi_%7B+%7D%28x%29%20%3D%20%5Csum_%7Bn%3D0%7D%5E%7B%5Cinfty%7D%20b_nx%5En)

Substituting these series into the Schrödinger equations and comparing coefficients, we find that the series are related by a recurrence relation. Solving the recurrence relation, we find that the series converges to Airy functions:

![equation](https://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?%5Cdpi%7B120%7D%20%5Cbg_white%20%5Cpsi_%7B-%7D%28x%29%20%3D%20A%5C%20Ai%28%5Calpha%20x%20+%20%5Cbeta%29)

![equation](https://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?%5Cdpi%7B120%7D%20%5Cbg_white%20%5Cpsi_%7B+%7D%28x%29%20%3D%20B%5C%20Ai%28-%5Calpha%20x%20+%20%5Cbeta%29)

where A and B are constants, α and β are related to the energy E and the constants a, b, and m, and Ai(x) is the Airy function.

Now we apply the boundary conditions:

1. ψ(-x_0) = ψ(x_0) = 0:

![equation](https://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?%5Cdpi%7B120%7D%20%5Cbg_white%20A%5C%20Ai%28%5Calpha%20%28-x_0%29%20+%20%5Cbeta%29%20%3D%20B%5C%20Ai%28%5Calpha%20x_0%20+%20%5Cbeta%29%20%3D%200)

2. Matching the solutions at x = 0, taking into account the delta function potential:

![equation](https://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?%5Cdpi%7B120%7D%20%5Cbg_white%20%5Cpsi_%7B-%7D%280%29%20%3D%20%5Cpsi_%7B+%7D%280%29)

![equation](https://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?%5Cdpi%7B120%7D%20%5Cbg_white%20%5Cfrac%7Bd%5Cpsi_%7B-%7D%7D%7Bdx%7D%5CBig%7C_%7Bx%3D0%7D%20-%20%5Cfrac%7Bd%5Cpsi_%7B+%7D%7D%7Bdx%7D%5CBig%7C_%7Bx%3D0%7D%20%3D%20%5Cfrac%7B2ma%7D%7B%5Chbar%5E2%7D%5Cpsi%280%29)

Solving these boundary conditions, we find the eigenvalues E and the corresponding eigenfunctions ψ(x). The eigenvalues will depend on the parameters a, b, m, and x_0, and the eigenfunctions will be given by the Airy functions with the appropriate constants A and B.
